EDITORIAL.
—41 VERY undergraduate, if not all the other students and alumni have
learned the new song, "We're Here to Win Again, Hopkins," the
. vVVVVVVVVVII .
w
words and music of which were written by J. Girvin Peters, '98.
V
The music is very snappy, and is well arranged for the piano. The
v •
•v
sentiment of the song is good, having one verse suitable for the football season and one for the lacrosse season. We have needed just
such a song, because "Veritas Vos Liberabit" is too serious and
• l• ivinorviiroing* •
dignified to be sung at an athletic event, and neither ''Rah, for Black
and Blue!" nor '`Our Alma Mater in Dixie Land" are suitable for a
football or lacrosse game. Another objection to all of our old songs,
is that the music is written merely for the harmony and not so that it can be played to
advantage on the piano. This is the second song that Mr. Peters has contributed to Hopkins,
having written both the words and music to "Rah, for Black and Blue!" which has become so
popular. On behalf of the students, we wish to thank Mr. Peters for giving us such a splendid song, and to urge him to continue to contribute songs and marches to Hopkins. We
regret that there is apparently no other Hopkins man who is capable of producing such admirable songs, but since such is the case, we shall have to depend upon Mr. Peters's genius to
supply us with new songs for several years to come.

T seems that at last Hopkins is to have a Dramatic Club. This is not
just mere rumor, as it has been for the past five or six years, but is an
actual fact. This year the matter was undertaken very quietly by
two
or three who were greatly interested in organizing such a club,
V
instead of calling a mass meeting as has been done every fall for at
V
least four years past. These few men went among the students and
found out all who were interested in dramatics, and having got
• vvvvvvvvvvv
enough men to promise to support such an enterprise, called a meeting at which officers were elected and rules drawn up. A play
will soon be decided upon and work will be commenced. We
understand that there is a student who has written a comic opera, and it is quite possible
that the club will produce this: We feel confident that the Dramatic Club will meet with
success and will be assisted by several of the professors.
No doubt, there will be many who will hoot at the idea of a Dramatic Club, but there
are always some people who will try to discourage any enterprise, until it has become
well established and successful, and then praise it and want to be associated with it. Let this
new organization be well supported by the students. We shall give a full account of the
matter in our next issue.

undergraduates get out of it? In the first place, they got a lot of

Then, we showed that we can lose a game like men. Did anybody ever see a Hopkins crowd take a defeat like that before? Not a sign of "soreness," not
a trace of childishness, but a fine spirit of manliness that would not be downed.
It was something we had long been dreaming of, this day when the rising tide of
Hopkins spirit should break the bounds of conservatism and overflow in some such way as
this. All who took part in that wild demonstration on Homewood field, whether they bore
the colors of St. John's or the Black and Blue, have something to remember with pride.
Best of all, we were given a glimpse of what it really means to the alumni to have been
Hopkins men. The fact that two or three of those who came made a round-trip of six thousand miles, shows what a strong feeling they have fcr their college.
The reunion was a revelation to the present students as well as to the alumni. Both
sides have profited by it. May both unite to give the University the full benefit of it all!

Congratulations "Ab," upon such a successful termination of your life of single
blessedness.

THE 'NEWS-LETTER.

4

TRAGEDIES IN MANUSCRIPTS.
CHARLES M. ANDREWS.

Historical science has its tragedies as well
as the medical sciences, but its victims are
valuable manuscripts, not human lives. The
long series of documentary sources, which
form the ultimate foundation upon which
history rests, is torn with rents and gaps that
are due to the accidents of history and the
carelessness of human beings. The greatest
regret of the historian is for the documents
that are lost, and his greatest hope, for the
ultimate recovery of some of them. Scarcely
sixty years have passed since the preservation of historical records has been raised to
the dignity of a separate and scientific pursuit, and their care and arrangement gained
the attention, not only of scholars, but of
governments also. It is difficult to realize today how careless men have been in the treatment of documents, and how little interest
they seem to have taken in records that are
deemed priceless at the present time.
For the accidents to which historical documents owe their destruction the individual
can hardly be held responsible, except that in
generally neglecting to furnish suitable accommodation for records, he has rendered them
liable to destruction by fire and water, the two
greatest enemies of the historian. Fires have
been the cause of the greatest tragedies in
historical science, and all archivists in all
countries • have their stories of losses or of
narrow escapes. Fires have destroyed great
collections containing thousands of documents
or have injured the papers to such an extent
as to place them beyond the hope of repair.
Some of the fires have been the deliberate acts
of invading armies: as when the British troops
burned the Capitol in Washington in 1814, or
the Federal troops, April 3, 1865, burned a
part of Richmond, including the Court House
in which were stored a great collections of
of ancient records. Such losses are unique
only in their magnitude. The burning of the
British Custom House in London, in 1814,
cost our scholars some of the most important
material for the history of colonial commerce;
the fire which burnt to the ground the old
Banquetting Hall of Whitehall, in 1619, destroyed many books and papers of the Privy
Council Office, leaving a gap of twelve years

in the history of that board; a fire, also in
Whitehall, in 1689 led to the loss of valuable
departmental papers, while the great fire of
London of 1666 and the burning of the Hotel
de Ville in Paris, in 1871 resulted in losses,
the extent of which can never adequately be
determined. When in 1834, the Parliament
Buildings were burnt it was only by great
presence of mind that the manuscripts of the
House of Lords were saved. One of the
greatest disasters in this country, though it
affected a somewhat narrower field of historical interest, occurred in 1906, when three
hundred volumes of Spanish archives of California, constituting the largest collections of
Spanish decrees, memorials, orders, and proceedings extant in the United States, were
entirely destroyed in the San Francisco earthquake and fire. It is more difficult to reconcile oneself to this loss when one remembers
that an offer from the Library of Congress to
receive these documents for safekeeping was
refused in 1902 by the citizens of San
Francisco.
Many losses have been incurred in the burning of private houses. The most famous
tragedy of this kind took place on October 23,
1731, when Ashburnham House at Westminister was burned, in which the priceless
collection of Sir Robert Cotton was stored,
and large numbers of manuscript volumes
were destroyed, or injured beyond repair. A
fire in the house of the historian, Mommsen,
resulted in the destruction of rare documents
loaned him by the German National Library,
for which he and his friends were compelled
to pay many thousand marks. More recently,
about 1890, the burning of the residence of a
Georgia professor led to the total destruction
of a set of twenty-two volume of manuscripts
from British archives, which had been loaned
to him for historical purposes by the State.
Fortunately these documents were only copies
and can be replaced. The sack of Thomas
Hutchinson's house by a mob in Boston,
August 26, 1765, and the scattering of his
papers in the street, resulted in serious losses,
through the manuscript of his history .was in
largest part preserved. Similarly, when the
house of the loyalist, Joseph Galloway, was
attacked in 1778 and his papers were scattered,
many valuable letters, including probably

THE NEWS-LETTER.

some of Benjamin Franklin, were 'lever recovered.
Losses by fire or by mob violence are to be
regreted, but they do not arouse the exasperation of the historian, as do the losses which
have been incurred through the indifference
or neglect of custodians. Two towns in
Onondago County, New York, burned up all
their old records, because they needed the
rooms in which they were stored. A superintendent of the Capitol in Nashville, Tennessee,
had 3000 great books, relating to the State
bank and its branches, ripped from their
covers and sold to the paper dealers, while the
covers were sent to a filling dump. Clerks,
attendants, and even higher officials, underpaid or receiving insufficient fees for their
maintenance, have sold the old parchments
and papers in their custody to make glue or to
be pulped for the making of new paper. Local
Virginia historians have recorded their sentiments at the sight of numerous fragments of
seals near a paper mill to which State
employees had been selling old documents.
A barrel of Franklin papers was recovered in
the nick of time from a paper mill in New
Jersey, and in not a few instances valuable
historical evidence has been obtained from the
parchment backing used in binding books of
modern date. More Franklin papers were
recovered some sixty years ago from a tailor's
shop in London, where the tailor was already
beginning to use them in making his paper
patterns. Even when not deliberately sold,
documents in official custody have been made
a quarry for the conscienceless collector. Custodians have taken advantage of their stewardship to reap some small gain from their
opportunity and have often driven hard bargains in selling either the documents them selves or the right to exploit them. As a
result stamps have been torn off, signatures
cut out, and even complete documents purloined. The enthusiasm for 'extra-illustrating," for gathering autographs and holographs, and for collecting prints, stamps,
and book-marks seems to dull the human
sense of honesty. To many men and women
the theft of a document seems but a small
offence. It has taken many years to impress
upon the world the sacredness of national
archives.

5

Less culpable, but no less serious, in its
consequences was the practice which prevailed
up to very recent times of carrying off the
records to private houses. Early judges and
government officials in England deemed court
rolls and state papers their private property,
and at the expiration of their term of office
carried them home. Hence such records
found their way into private collections, into
the chests containing the family archives, or
into the hands of the auctioneers in the great
book-shops. This practice explains why so
many state papers are today either in private
hands or in possession of great libraries like
the British Museum. Hundreds of papers
thus taken were of course lost, and there are
periods and phases of English history, notably
in the first quarter of the nineteenth century,
for which source material is disheartingly
meagre on account of the abstractions of official papers by persons in service under the
government. George Chalmers, clerk of the
Council Committee of Trade, and once a lawyer in Baltimore, frequently borrowed manuscript volumes of the Board of Trade, and
many of these he never returned, a fact that
is known from the actual record of his loans
which is still preserved. Of the library founded
by the munificence of Richard Whitington at
the Guildhall three cart-loads of volumes,
all manuscripts, were lent to Protector Somerset in the reign of Edward VI, and on his
downfall in 1552 were irrecoverably lost. Occasionally lost documents can be traced, and
the Cecil, Harleian, Cottonian, and other
great private collections disclose papers that
ought by right of origin to be in official
custody.
The gross neglect which has characterized
the care of records in the past is one of the
least pardonable of all the sins against the
writing of history. Of some thirty reports
made during the last decade upon our State
archives there is not one but contains its tale
of woe. Placed in charge of ignorant and
careless custodians, to whom often an ancient
document is a useless incumbrance, valuable
records have been relegated to any place of
deposit not wanted for other purposes. In
garrets, lofts, closets, and bins, in tanks,
vaults, coal holes, and stables, these records
have been subjected to every kind of indignity.

6

THE NEWS-LETTER.

They have been drenched with water, soaked
with the filth of leaking sewers, rotted with
the damp and mold of underground cellars,
scattered by the wind during repairs to buildings, trodden under foot while lying in corridors used for daily passage, transformed into
festering heaps of useless and dangerous material, ravaged by mice and vermin, and in
cases where still in use were allowed to remain
unrepaired and to be worn away bit by bit
until reduced to fragments too fragile and
tattered to be of service. Each one of these
statements could be proved by an overwhelming, mass of evidence. Little wonder that
papers thus neglected are subjected to vandalism and plunder. Who can blame the janitor
that uses such papers found in a cellar to start
his fires, as happened in the case of the public
archives of Delaware. The blame falls on
those in authority, who out of a mistaken
sense of economy, have failed to make any
adequate provision, in the way of housing or
staff, for the preservation and classification of
the papers.
But the dark ages are passing. Urged on
by the private student and the literary worker,
and by historical associations and influential
committees, governments are rising to a sense
of their responsibility and to an appreciation
of the national disgrace. In great repositories
like the Bibliotheque Nationale, the Public
Record Office, the British Museum, and the
Library of Congress a document is cared for
as a thrice welcome guest. In fire-proof surroundings, on dry and commodious shelves,
bound in volumes or laid in boxes, the
neglectea and abused record has at last returned to its own. The British Museum
rejects no fragment, even though it be but a
blank paper. All great archives devote to the
repair of documents a skill that is little short
of marvelous. Holes are filled in, rents
brought together, ragged edges guarded, folds
ironed out, fragile papers covered with linen
tissue, and then these renovated papers and
parchments are bound or filed, classified,
ticketted, stamped, and arranged for convenient use. To tamper with such a document,
to tear it, mark it, or carry it away, subjects
the guilty person to rejection from the repository. Though a great deal yet remains to be
done in the lesser repositories, and though

large numbers of documents of great value
still remain in private hands constantly subject to loss, yet in the main it may be said
that the sacredness of historical records is at
last recognized and tlw eventual concentration of the majority of such records in safe
quarters is now only a matter of time.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
SIR —In view of the recent discussion in
your columns of a proposed treaty betwcen
fraternities, there are several points, I think,
which have not been sufficiently emphasized.
An inter-fraternity treaty, in the first place,
must be an agreement, made solely for the
general welfare, and based on the consent al d
approval of all. It does not contemplate a
bargain by which each fraternity benefits. itself, at the expense of some other fraternity.
A treaty based solely upon the idea of force
and of penalties cannot succeed. The word
'treaty' suggests an agreement which it is to
the interests of all to preserve, not an opportunity for the parties to that treaty to elude
its provisions. A I understand it, the general
provisions are suggested as benefits, not as
restrictions to be imposed and enforced through
stern penalties.
I will not admit so great a lack of confidence among ourselves that an agreement of
this nature is impossible; nor do I believe that
there is wanting a general feeling that an ei:d
should be set to the recognized abuse of early
pledging.
Yours very truly,

GEORGE E. Ross VEAZEY.

FIRST STUDENT BIBLE CONFERENCE.
Inspired by the gigantic forward strides of
organized student Bible study, with its revolutionary effect on the lives of individuals and
colleges, the first International Bible Conference was called to convene at Columbus, Ohio,
October 22-25, to consider the further extension of Bible study in the colleges of North
America. There were present 1022 delegates
representing 220 institutions of the United
States and Canada. It was a truly representative college assembly containing men prominent in the athletic, the social and the intel-

THE NEWS-LETTER.

lectual , sides of college life. Members of
faculties were among the delegates as well as
among the speakers. Realizing the college
conditions of America, as only such a body of
men could, it goes without emphasizing that
their deliberations were carried on with great
judgment and wisdom. A distinctive feature
of the conference was the marvelous earnestness of spirit; the aim was not to magnify and
extend the student Bible study propaganda,
but rather to bring some tangible force for
goodness and greatness to the individual, to
the college and to the nation.
The importance of student Bible study, as
portrayed by the results of the past five years,
is no less interesting than significant. During
the last year there were 048,882 men enrolled
in Bible classes in the colleges of North
America, 33,663 of whom attended two months
or more. There were 6,740 men holding
positions of prominence in college life of 364
institutions, 4,022 fraternity man in 125 institutions, and 3,898 non-Christian men in
217 institutions enrolled in Bible study classes.
Probably the most striking evidence that the
student Bible study movement is a great and
far-reaching propaganda destined to touch
eventually every student of North America in
one way or another was given by individuals
representing the various colleges and schools.
Col. Lamed, of West Point, told of the
strenuosity of life and strictness of discipline
that the Army Cadets are forced to undergo,
and how every hour of the day, save 40 or 45
minutes, has something mapped out for them.
In spite of this very serious handicap there
are, of the 415 cadets, 245, or about'60% enrolled in Bible study courses requiring 15 or
20 minutes of daily study. There are in
Bible study 46 of 106 seniors, 5 of 10 honor
men, the captains of baseball and football
teams, a group composed solely of football
men, and 11 of the 18 senior cadet officers.
The movement at Yale has increased in
three years from 500 men in eight groups to
about 1,000 men in ninety groups. There
are 27 dormitory classes, in fact every "dorm"
has at least one, besides one in the training
house. At the University of Toronto, the
number jumped from 152 in '06—'07 to 950
last year. There were more than 700 enrolled
at the time of the Columbus conference, with

7

only 200 men belonging to the Y. M. C. A.
The University of Texas had 600 men in
classes with twelve different fraternity groups.
At Cornell the enrollment increased from 330
in '06—'07 to 742 last year.
The University of Illinois was the banner
college of America in Bible study last year,
having 1,050 men enrolled, with 802 attending two months or longer. There were thirteen
fraternity Bible study groups containing 300
of the 500 fraternity men. This year practically every fraternity is anxious to have a
Class, and it is confidently expected that
almost the entire fraternity body will enroll.
These are typical institutions and many other
equally interesting accounts could be cited.
It is, beyond a reasonable doubt true, that
Bible study among students is gathering momentum and becoming more and more a part
of student life. It can be justly asked, "What
good is resulting therefrom?" "What is the
fundamental purpose of this movement?"
The answer unhesitatingly comes, "The
symmetrical development of the college man
in his life work." We dub the man a "grind"
who develops nothing but his mental faculties.
The fellow who does everything else but study
we call a "sport" or even some more inglorious name. The man who combines the
qualities of the "grind" and the "sport" is
known as a "good all-around fellow." Now
it is a matter of general knowledge that these
three classes, in many cases, fail to make
good. The reason is, lack of symmetrical development or rather lack of spirit. By spirit
I don't mean altogether bull-dog tenacity and
persistance, rather a deeper consciousness that
gives a man a constant, dignified and unaffected poise. This, to my mind, is the mission
of Bible study among college men. The study
of the Bible not only puts men in touch with
the world's most significant personalities, but
it also reports the experience of men with
higher powers and with that Spirit whose
presence makes them clean and strong and
noble.
It is a matter of the largest concern to every
man, what he is going to be to his home, his
community, his State and his nation. It has
been proven again and again that it is totally
insufficient for a man to simply desire to be
just and kind in his dealings with his fellows;

THE NEWS-LETTER.

8

in order to be so there must be some fundamental principles or creed back of that desire.
The philosophy of Christ, as laid down in the
New Testament, is matchless, and is so conceded by every class of mind. To what better
place can a man go for his creed, and to what
better place can a nation look for the inspiration of her cleanest and best.statesmen, jurists,
financiers and men of affairs?

• J. F. HUNTER,
Delegate from Johns Hopkins.

HOPKINS NIGHT.
On Friday night, December 11th, there
will be once again what is called Hopkins
Night, at Ford's Grand Opera House. This
should be one of the greatest events of the
year for the Hopkins students. The special
attraction of the evening is "The Girl Question," which is known to be one of the best
shows of the season. It ran before crowded
hOuses for a whole year in the city of Chicago.
Other features of this show were mentioned
in the last number of THE NEWS-LETTER.
The name of the show is one which should
attract any student of the University.
Another attraction, one which is fully as
interesting as is the show, has been planned
by the committee in charge of the arrangements. Mr. Albert Ritchie, known all over the
city as an after:dinner speaker, has consented
to speak between the acts. He will be introduced by Prof. H. P. Mustard. Everyone
knows that he can count on hearing • a
cracker-jack" speech from Mr. Dashiell,
and also that he will be favored with number•
less interesting remarks by Prof. Mustard.
It is hoped that every student enrolled at
the University will take this opportunity of
helping out the 1909 Hullabaloo and ot showing Baltimore people how much we all honor
and respect old Hopkins.
Tickets can be brought from students, or at
the cloak room. Everybody come down and
help swell the throng.
As a last remark, don't buy only one
ticket, buy two. For it is an established fact
that the girls as well as the boys are interested
in the '`Girl Question."

THE MUSICAL CLUBS.
A meeting of the Musical Clubs was held at
1 P. M., Wednesday, November 18, 1908, in
McCoy Hall. There were thirty men present,
twenty-three of these were old men and the
remainder freshmen. Such an interest is a
source of great joy to the president, and he
hopes that this attendance, as good as it is,
will be bettered.
The meeting was called to order by President Perce, who at once congratulated the
members present upon the fine attendance,
and urged upon them the necessity of having
a large membership. A roll call showed that
there were two pianists present, about four
violinists, quite a number of mandolinists,
while almost everyone present claimed to be
something of a singer.
Officers for the season of 1908-1909 were
elected as follows:
Franklin B. Pedrick, '09, President.
John Gardner Murray, Jr., '11, Manager.
Samuel Seymour Merrick, '11, Director of
Mandolins.
Thomas DeC. Ruth, graduate, Director of
Glee Club.
The assistant-managership is still open. A
person, it is hoped of the freshman class, will
be picked to fill this office. All members wishing to try for the position are requested to
hand their names to the manager,P.O.Box 403.
It is hoped that the interest shown by the
freshmen at this meeting will not die out, but
that they will awake to the fact that -if you
want to have fun" come out for the musical
clubs. Every one present Wednesday seemed
to be in for the welfare of the club. The general speech was -Let's have another Woman's
College concert and some trips."
The Manager has already started to make
arrangements for a joint concert with the Woman's College, and it is not improbable that
such a concert will be arranged with the University of Virginia. In addition to these two
large affairs he has promised to arrange for
several trips. It is to be hoped that he will
not forget National Park, Annapolis, Easton,
Cambridge, Sykesville, Hagerstown, Frederick, and last, but not least, Waterbury. So far
every prospect for the season is a bright one.
Good attendance at the first meeting, great
interest manifested, and all old bills paid, bid
fair to make this season one of the brightest in
the history of the Clubs. It is up to the Clubs.
Come out and the president, managers and
leaders will make you enjoy every moment
you put in it.

1908-FOOTBALL SEASON-1908.
FRESHMAN FOOTBALL TEAM.
Once in the history of the freshmen-junior
football games has the freshman team come
out victorious. This year the opponents of
the freshmen are sophomores instead of juniors. The name sophomore sounds much
more terrible than juniors, but the freshmen
are determined, and have good reason for feel-

Come stand together and raise a cheer for
the best football team that ever wore the
Black and Blue, the team of 1908. Taking
the season as a whole, it has made a great
record. The following figures speak for
themselves: 1907, Hopkins scored 7 points to
their opponents' 52; 1908, Hopkins scored 65
points to their opponents' 43.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

10

There is another great feature in the football season of 1908, and that is, that it proves
the success of the movement for an undergraduate team, which was started last year.
The speed and teamwork of our eleven have
opened the eyes of local football enthusiasts;
and the crowds that have attended the games
at Homewood mark a new era in Hopkins
athletics.
It is true that we lost two games. But
these games were lost under such conditions,
that they do not detract from the glory due
the team. In the game with Delaware the
field was covered with slush, and three substitutes were in the Hopkins line. No more
is needed to explain the defeat. In the game
on the following Saturday, with St. John's,
all of the fates—Clotho, Lachesis and Atropos
—were against Hopkins. As a result, no
matter how much ground our fellows gained,
they could not win.
The final game of the season with the
Baltimore Medical College shows well the
For although the
spirit of our eleven.
redoubtable Bridgman was out of the game,
and all the advantage of weight were against
them, the Black and Blue line held tight, and
the Black and Blue backs tore up the line of
the enemy, and the victory was ours.
Let's all give three ringing cheers for the
best team that ever wore the Black and Blue
—the team of 1908.

THE FIFTH REGIMENT MEET.
Although our track men have not started
their regular training, those who were entered
in the meet held at the Fifth Regiment
Armory, on the night after tile St. John's
game did splendid work. Ben. Tappan defeated a good field in the high jump. The
form that he displayed so early in the season.
promises well for his work in future meets.
Keith Martin ran his first race for the
Black and Blue in the 100-yard hurdles. He
won his heat, and in the finals finished a
scant foot behind the winner. Captain Baily
and Leo Gutman ran well in the preliminary
heats of the 100-yard dash, but lack of training prevented them from being placed in the
finals. — Dutch" Breyer started to run the
mile, but he had lost all his wind rooting for
Hopkins against St. John's and dropped out
two laps short of the finish.

ATHLETIC NOTES.
"Billy" Hoffman, '02, captain of the track
team of his year, has been appointed track
coach for the season. The matter of the
coach has been hanging for a long time, and
his final appointment will enable Captain
Baily to get his men down to consistent work.
.Anyone who follows athletics will remember
Mr. Hoffman, who can be depended on to get
out the best team possible.
Mr, Seymour Merrick, '11, has been elected
manager for the football season of 1909. The
good record made by the team this year has
already been the direct cause of the receipt of
many letters from teams of first caliber requesting games, and it looks as if the University would have one of the best schedules in
its history.
The Athletic Board, at a special meeting,
Monday afternoon, awarded the 'Varsity
"H" to the following men: Captain Stockton,
Chauncey Bosley, Eveleth Bridgman, "Dick"
McCabe, "Jack" Fulton, "Babe" Michael,
Harvey Musser, "Ham" Owens, Stoney
Stollenwerck, "Doc" Streett and "Doc"
Bryan. "Bill" Tilghman, Beehler, Frey,
Huck, "Dud" Lawton, "Teedy" Lurman,
"Billy" Martin, Saltzer and Reaney Wolf were
given the "H. A. A." All the awards were
for football, of course.
Another important decision reached by the
board was the determination to drop the Baltimore Medical College and Delaware from
the football schedule. Delaware was dropped
because of the determination of the management that none but teams who are of sufficient
prominence to prove good drawing cards be
played. No one who saw the B. M. C. game
of Thanksgiving day, will need ask why they
were dropped.

THE ALUMNI REUNION. WHAT OF IT?
Well, it's all over. There is one question,
though, which should be, and is, I hope, in
everyone's mind. What has been the result?
What good will the reunion, so much talked
of, bring about? The answers to these, and
similar questions, depend on whether the
former strong college spirit of the old Hopkins men was aroused; it depends on. whether
the present students at Johns Hopkins have
called forth enthusiasm with enthusiasm. You
probably think that it is too late to take up
this last phase of the matter, that we have
shown as much spirit as we could, and that
we can only wait passively for the result. It
is too late to actually catch the attention of
the Alumni, but is that any sort of a reason
why we should remain idle? Do you really
think we have done our best? If not, why
stop? Don't let's have any one ready to 'quit!"
We must all work harder than ever, and
whoop things along, both to keep those of the
Alumni we have, interested, and to fight for
the interest and backing of many more.

REUNION NOTES.
Ninety-two's snappy yell was heard on all
occasions:
Rah, Blue!
Rah, Black!
Johnny Hopkins, Ninety-two!
The cheering and even the songs could be
heard at Roland Park, nearly a mile from
Homewood field, with such distinctness that
hearers could tell the concerted cheers from
the spontaneous yelling.
It would be a great stunt to perpetuate the
war dance" after the game as a sort of
regular custom at the St. John's football game
and at the Swarthmore lacrosse game. The
big crowd that remained to see it this time
proves that outsiders find it interesting.
It was far and away the largest crowd ever
seen at a Hopkins game.
Ever see a Hopkins crowd take a defeat that
way before?

SENIOR CLASS POEM.
The 1909 Hullabaloo Board, in whose hands
the class has placed the selection of the Class
Poem, has decided upon the following conditions:
The competion is open only to members of
the Class of 1909. The poems must be
placed in the hands of the Chief Editor of the
book, before February 1st, 1909. The form
and contents of the poem is left entirely to the
competitors; suggestions may be found in
previous class-books. The author of the best
poem will be appointed Class Poet, and his
composition will be printed in the Hullabaloo,
the board reserving the right to use any of the
unsuccessful poems.

T seems that at last Hopkins is to have a Dramatic Club. This is not
just mere rumor, as it has been for the past five or six years, but is an
actual fact. This year the matter was undertaken very quietly by
two
or three who were greatly interested in organizing such a club,

TRAGEDIES IN MANUSCRIPTS.
CHARLES M. ANDREWS.

Historical science has its tragedies as well
as the medical sciences, but its victims are
valuable manuscripts, not human lives. The
long series of documentary sources, which
form the ultimate foundation upon which
history rests, is torn with rents and gaps that
are due to the accidents of history and the
carelessness of human beings. The greatest
regret of the historian is for the documents
that are lost, and his greatest hope, for the
ultimate recovery of some of them. Scarcely
sixty years have passed since the preservation of historical records has been raised to
the dignity of a separate and scientific pursuit, and their care and arrangement gained
the attention, not only of scholars, but of
governments also. It is difficult to realize today how careless men have been in the treatment of documents, and how little interest
they seem to have taken in records that are
deemed priceless at the present time.
For the accidents to which historical documents owe their destruction the individual
can hardly be held responsible, except that in
generally neglecting to furnish suitable accommodation for records, he has rendered them
liable to destruction by fire and water, the two
greatest enemies of the historian. Fires have
been the cause of the greatest tragedies in
historical science, and all archivists in all
countries • have their stories of losses or of
narrow escapes. Fires have destroyed great
collections containing thousands of documents
or have injured the papers to such an extent
as to place them beyond the hope of repair.
Some of the fires have been the deliberate acts
of invading armies: as when the British troops
burned the Capitol in Washington in 1814, or
the Federal troops, April 3, 1865, burned a
part of Richmond, including the Court House
in which were stored a great collections of
of ancient records. Such losses are unique
only in their magnitude. The burning of the
British Custom House in London, in 1814,
cost our scholars some of the most important
material for the history of colonial commerce;
the fire which burnt to the ground the old
Banquetting Hall of Whitehall, in 1619, destroyed many books and papers of the Privy
Council Office, leaving a gap of twelve years

in the history of that board; a fire, also in
Whitehall, in 1689 led to the loss of valuable
departmental papers, while the great fire of
London of 1666 and the burning of the Hotel
de Ville in Paris, in 1871 resulted in losses,
the extent of which can never adequately be
determined. When in 1834, the Parliament
Buildings were burnt it was only by great
presence of mind that the manuscripts of the
House of Lords were saved. One of the
greatest disasters in this country, though it
affected a somewhat narrower field of historical interest, occurred in 1906, when three
hundred volumes of Spanish archives of California, constituting the largest collections of
Spanish decrees, memorials, orders, and proceedings extant in the United States, were
entirely destroyed in the San Francisco earthquake and fire. It is more difficult to reconcile oneself to this loss when one remembers
that an offer from the Library of Congress to
receive these documents for safekeeping was
refused in 1902 by the citizens of San
Francisco.
Many losses have been incurred in the burning of private houses. The most famous
tragedy of this kind took place on October 23,
1731, when Ashburnham House at Westminister was burned, in which the priceless
collection of Sir Robert Cotton was stored,
and large numbers of manuscript volumes
were destroyed, or injured beyond repair. A
fire in the house of the historian, Mommsen,
resulted in the destruction of rare documents
loaned him by the German National Library,
for which he and his friends were compelled
to pay many thousand marks. More recently,
about 1890, the burning of the residence of a
Georgia professor led to the total destruction
of a set of twenty-two volume of manuscripts
from British archives, which had been loaned
to him for historical purposes by the State.
Fortunately these documents were only copies
and can be replaced. The sack of Thomas
Hutchinson's house by a mob in Boston,
August 26, 1765, and the scattering of his
papers in the street, resulted in serious losses,
through the manuscript of his history .was in
largest part preserved. Similarly, when the
house of the loyalist, Joseph Galloway, was
attacked in 1778 and his papers were scattered,
many valuable letters, including probably

THE NEWS-LETTER.

some of Benjamin Franklin, were 'lever recovered.
Losses by fire or by mob violence are to be
regreted, but they do not arouse the exasperation of the historian, as do the losses which
have been incurred through the indifference
or neglect of custodians. Two towns in
Onondago County, New York, burned up all
their old records, because they needed the
rooms in which they were stored. A superintendent of the Capitol in Nashville, Tennessee,
had 3000 great books, relating to the State
bank and its branches, ripped from their
covers and sold to the paper dealers, while the
covers were sent to a filling dump. Clerks,
attendants, and even higher officials, underpaid or receiving insufficient fees for their
maintenance, have sold the old parchments
and papers in their custody to make glue or to
be pulped for the making of new paper. Local
Virginia historians have recorded their sentiments at the sight of numerous fragments of
seals near a paper mill to which State
employees had been selling old documents.
A barrel of Franklin papers was recovered in
the nick of time from a paper mill in New
Jersey, and in not a few instances valuable
historical evidence has been obtained from the
parchment backing used in binding books of
modern date. More Franklin papers were
recovered some sixty years ago from a tailor's
shop in London, where the tailor was already
beginning to use them in making his paper
patterns. Even when not deliberately sold,
documents in official custody have been made
a quarry for the conscienceless collector. Custodians have taken advantage of their stewardship to reap some small gain from their
opportunity and have often driven hard bargains in selling either the documents them selves or the right to exploit them. As a
result stamps have been torn off, signatures
cut out, and even complete documents purloined. The enthusiasm for 'extra-illustrating," for gathering autographs and holographs, and for collecting prints, stamps,
and book-marks seems to dull the human
sense of honesty. To many men and women
the theft of a document seems but a small
offence. It has taken many years to impress
upon the world the sacredness of national
archives.

5

Less culpable, but no less serious, in its
consequences was the practice which prevailed
up to very recent times of carrying off the
records to private houses. Early judges and
government officials in England deemed court
rolls and state papers their private property,
and at the expiration of their term of office
carried them home. Hence such records
found their way into private collections, into
the chests containing the family archives, or
into the hands of the auctioneers in the great
book-shops. This practice explains why so
many state papers are today either in private
hands or in possession of great libraries like
the British Museum. Hundreds of papers
thus taken were of course lost, and there are
periods and phases of English history, notably
in the first quarter of the nineteenth century,
for which source material is disheartingly
meagre on account of the abstractions of official papers by persons in service under the
government. George Chalmers, clerk of the
Council Committee of Trade, and once a lawyer in Baltimore, frequently borrowed manuscript volumes of the Board of Trade, and
many of these he never returned, a fact that
is known from the actual record of his loans
which is still preserved. Of the library founded
by the munificence of Richard Whitington at
the Guildhall three cart-loads of volumes,
all manuscripts, were lent to Protector Somerset in the reign of Edward VI, and on his
downfall in 1552 were irrecoverably lost. Occasionally lost documents can be traced, and
the Cecil, Harleian, Cottonian, and other
great private collections disclose papers that
ought by right of origin to be in official
custody.
The gross neglect which has characterized
the care of records in the past is one of the
least pardonable of all the sins against the
writing of history. Of some thirty reports
made during the last decade upon our State
archives there is not one but contains its tale
of woe. Placed in charge of ignorant and
careless custodians, to whom often an ancient
document is a useless incumbrance, valuable
records have been relegated to any place of
deposit not wanted for other purposes. In
garrets, lofts, closets, and bins, in tanks,
vaults, coal holes, and stables, these records
have been subjected to every kind of indignity.

6

THE NEWS-LETTER.

They have been drenched with water, soaked
with the filth of leaking sewers, rotted with
the damp and mold of underground cellars,
scattered by the wind during repairs to buildings, trodden under foot while lying in corridors used for daily passage, transformed into
festering heaps of useless and dangerous material, ravaged by mice and vermin, and in
cases where still in use were allowed to remain
unrepaired and to be worn away bit by bit
until reduced to fragments too fragile and
tattered to be of service. Each one of these
statements could be proved by an overwhelming, mass of evidence. Little wonder that
papers thus neglected are subjected to vandalism and plunder. Who can blame the janitor
that uses such papers found in a cellar to start
his fires, as happened in the case of the public
archives of Delaware. The blame falls on
those in authority, who out of a mistaken
sense of economy, have failed to make any
adequate provision, in the way of housing or
staff, for the preservation and classification of
the papers.
But the dark ages are passing. Urged on
by the private student and the literary worker,
and by historical associations and influential
committees, governments are rising to a sense
of their responsibility and to an appreciation
of the national disgrace. In great repositories
like the Bibliotheque Nationale, the Public
Record Office, the British Museum, and the
Library of Congress a document is cared for
as a thrice welcome guest. In fire-proof surroundings, on dry and commodious shelves,
bound in volumes or laid in boxes, the
neglectea and abused record has at last returned to its own. The British Museum
rejects no fragment, even though it be but a
blank paper. All great archives devote to the
repair of documents a skill that is little short
of marvelous. Holes are filled in, rents
brought together, ragged edges guarded, folds
ironed out, fragile papers covered with linen
tissue, and then these renovated papers and
parchments are bound or filed, classified,
ticketted, stamped, and arranged for convenient use. To tamper with such a document,
to tear it, mark it, or carry it away, subjects
the guilty person to rejection from the repository. Though a great deal yet remains to be
done in the lesser repositories, and though

large numbers of documents of great value
still remain in private hands constantly subject to loss, yet in the main it may be said
that the sacredness of historical records is at
last recognized and tlw eventual concentration of the majority of such records in safe
quarters is now only a matter of time.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
SIR —In view of the recent discussion in
your columns of a proposed treaty betwcen
fraternities, there are several points, I think,
which have not been sufficiently emphasized.
An inter-fraternity treaty, in the first place,
must be an agreement, made solely for the
general welfare, and based on the consent al d
approval of all. It does not contemplate a
bargain by which each fraternity benefits. itself, at the expense of some other fraternity.
A treaty based solely upon the idea of force
and of penalties cannot succeed. The word
'treaty' suggests an agreement which it is to
the interests of all to preserve, not an opportunity for the parties to that treaty to elude
its provisions. A I understand it, the general
provisions are suggested as benefits, not as
restrictions to be imposed and enforced through
stern penalties.
I will not admit so great a lack of confidence among ourselves that an agreement of
this nature is impossible; nor do I believe that
there is wanting a general feeling that an ei:d
should be set to the recognized abuse of early
pledging.
Yours very truly,

GEORGE E. Ross VEAZEY.

FIRST STUDENT BIBLE CONFERENCE.
Inspired by the gigantic forward strides of
organized student Bible study, with its revolutionary effect on the lives of individuals and
colleges, the first International Bible Conference was called to convene at Columbus, Ohio,
October 22-25, to consider the further extension of Bible study in the colleges of North
America. There were present 1022 delegates
representing 220 institutions of the United
States and Canada. It was a truly representative college assembly containing men prominent in the athletic, the social and the intel-

THE NEWS-LETTER.

lectual , sides of college life. Members of
faculties were among the delegates as well as
among the speakers. Realizing the college
conditions of America, as only such a body of
men could, it goes without emphasizing that
their deliberations were carried on with great
judgment and wisdom. A distinctive feature
of the conference was the marvelous earnestness of spirit; the aim was not to magnify and
extend the student Bible study propaganda,
but rather to bring some tangible force for
goodness and greatness to the individual, to
the college and to the nation.
The importance of student Bible study, as
portrayed by the results of the past five years,
is no less interesting than significant. During
the last year there were 048,882 men enrolled
in Bible classes in the colleges of North
America, 33,663 of whom attended two months
or more. There were 6,740 men holding
positions of prominence in college life of 364
institutions, 4,022 fraternity man in 125 institutions, and 3,898 non-Christian men in
217 institutions enrolled in Bible study classes.
Probably the most striking evidence that the
student Bible study movement is a great and
far-reaching propaganda destined to touch
eventually every student of North America in
one way or another was given by individuals
representing the various colleges and schools.
Col. Lamed, of West Point, told of the
strenuosity of life and strictness of discipline
that the Army Cadets are forced to undergo,
and how every hour of the day, save 40 or 45
minutes, has something mapped out for them.
In spite of this very serious handicap there
are, of the 415 cadets, 245, or about'60% enrolled in Bible study courses requiring 15 or
20 minutes of daily study. There are in
Bible study 46 of 106 seniors, 5 of 10 honor
men, the captains of baseball and football
teams, a group composed solely of football
men, and 11 of the 18 senior cadet officers.
The movement at Yale has increased in
three years from 500 men in eight groups to
about 1,000 men in ninety groups. There
are 27 dormitory classes, in fact every "dorm"
has at least one, besides one in the training
house. At the University of Toronto, the
number jumped from 152 in '06—'07 to 950
last year. There were more than 700 enrolled
at the time of the Columbus conference, with

7

only 200 men belonging to the Y. M. C. A.
The University of Texas had 600 men in
classes with twelve different fraternity groups.
At Cornell the enrollment increased from 330
in '06—'07 to 742 last year.
The University of Illinois was the banner
college of America in Bible study last year,
having 1,050 men enrolled, with 802 attending two months or longer. There were thirteen
fraternity Bible study groups containing 300
of the 500 fraternity men. This year practically every fraternity is anxious to have a
Class, and it is confidently expected that
almost the entire fraternity body will enroll.
These are typical institutions and many other
equally interesting accounts could be cited.
It is, beyond a reasonable doubt true, that
Bible study among students is gathering momentum and becoming more and more a part
of student life. It can be justly asked, "What
good is resulting therefrom?" "What is the
fundamental purpose of this movement?"
The answer unhesitatingly comes, "The
symmetrical development of the college man
in his life work." We dub the man a "grind"
who develops nothing but his mental faculties.
The fellow who does everything else but study
we call a "sport" or even some more inglorious name. The man who combines the
qualities of the "grind" and the "sport" is
known as a "good all-around fellow." Now
it is a matter of general knowledge that these
three classes, in many cases, fail to make
good. The reason is, lack of symmetrical development or rather lack of spirit. By spirit
I don't mean altogether bull-dog tenacity and
persistance, rather a deeper consciousness that
gives a man a constant, dignified and unaffected poise. This, to my mind, is the mission
of Bible study among college men. The study
of the Bible not only puts men in touch with
the world's most significant personalities, but
it also reports the experience of men with
higher powers and with that Spirit whose
presence makes them clean and strong and
noble.
It is a matter of the largest concern to every
man, what he is going to be to his home, his
community, his State and his nation. It has
been proven again and again that it is totally
insufficient for a man to simply desire to be
just and kind in his dealings with his fellows;

THE NEWS-LETTER.

8

in order to be so there must be some fundamental principles or creed back of that desire.
The philosophy of Christ, as laid down in the
New Testament, is matchless, and is so conceded by every class of mind. To what better
place can a man go for his creed, and to what
better place can a nation look for the inspiration of her cleanest and best.statesmen, jurists,
financiers and men of affairs?

• J. F. HUNTER,
Delegate from Johns Hopkins.

HOPKINS NIGHT.
On Friday night, December 11th, there
will be once again what is called Hopkins
Night, at Ford's Grand Opera House. This
should be one of the greatest events of the
year for the Hopkins students. The special
attraction of the evening is "The Girl Question," which is known to be one of the best
shows of the season. It ran before crowded
hOuses for a whole year in the city of Chicago.
Other features of this show were mentioned
in the last number of THE NEWS-LETTER.
The name of the show is one which should
attract any student of the University.
Another attraction, one which is fully as
interesting as is the show, has been planned
by the committee in charge of the arrangements. Mr. Albert Ritchie, known all over the
city as an after:dinner speaker, has consented
to speak between the acts. He will be introduced by Prof. H. P. Mustard. Everyone
knows that he can count on hearing • a
cracker-jack" speech from Mr. Dashiell,
and also that he will be favored with number•
less interesting remarks by Prof. Mustard.
It is hoped that every student enrolled at
the University will take this opportunity of
helping out the 1909 Hullabaloo and ot showing Baltimore people how much we all honor
and respect old Hopkins.
Tickets can be brought from students, or at
the cloak room. Everybody come down and
help swell the throng.
As a last remark, don't buy only one
ticket, buy two. For it is an established fact
that the girls as well as the boys are interested
in the '`Girl Question."

THE MUSICAL CLUBS.
A meeting of the Musical Clubs was held at
1 P. M., Wednesday, November 18, 1908, in
McCoy Hall. There were thirty men present,
twenty-three of these were old men and the
remainder freshmen. Such an interest is a
source of great joy to the president, and he
hopes that this attendance, as good as it is,
will be bettered.
The meeting was called to order by President Perce, who at once congratulated the
members present upon the fine attendance,
and urged upon them the necessity of having
a large membership. A roll call showed that
there were two pianists present, about four
violinists, quite a number of mandolinists,
while almost everyone present claimed to be
something of a singer.
Officers for the season of 1908-1909 were
elected as follows:
Franklin B. Pedrick, '09, President.
John Gardner Murray, Jr., '11, Manager.
Samuel Seymour Merrick, '11, Director of
Mandolins.
Thomas DeC. Ruth, graduate, Director of
Glee Club.
The assistant-managership is still open. A
person, it is hoped of the freshman class, will
be picked to fill this office. All members wishing to try for the position are requested to
hand their names to the manager,P.O.Box 403.
It is hoped that the interest shown by the
freshmen at this meeting will not die out, but
that they will awake to the fact that -if you
want to have fun" come out for the musical
clubs. Every one present Wednesday seemed
to be in for the welfare of the club. The general speech was -Let's have another Woman's
College concert and some trips."
The Manager has already started to make
arrangements for a joint concert with the Woman's College, and it is not improbable that
such a concert will be arranged with the University of Virginia. In addition to these two
large affairs he has promised to arrange for
several trips. It is to be hoped that he will
not forget National Park, Annapolis, Easton,
Cambridge, Sykesville, Hagerstown, Frederick, and last, but not least, Waterbury. So far
every prospect for the season is a bright one.
Good attendance at the first meeting, great
interest manifested, and all old bills paid, bid
fair to make this season one of the brightest in
the history of the Clubs. It is up to the Clubs.
Come out and the president, managers and
leaders will make you enjoy every moment
you put in it.

1908-FOOTBALL SEASON-1908.
FRESHMAN FOOTBALL TEAM.
Once in the history of the freshmen-junior
football games has the freshman team come
out victorious. This year the opponents of
the freshmen are sophomores instead of juniors. The name sophomore sounds much
more terrible than juniors, but the freshmen
are determined, and have good reason for feel-

Come stand together and raise a cheer for
the best football team that ever wore the
Black and Blue, the team of 1908. Taking
the season as a whole, it has made a great
record. The following figures speak for
themselves: 1907, Hopkins scored 7 points to
their opponents' 52; 1908, Hopkins scored 65
points to their opponents' 43.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

10

There is another great feature in the football season of 1908, and that is, that it proves
the success of the movement for an undergraduate team, which was started last year.
The speed and teamwork of our eleven have
opened the eyes of local football enthusiasts;
and the crowds that have attended the games
at Homewood mark a new era in Hopkins
athletics.
It is true that we lost two games. But
these games were lost under such conditions,
that they do not detract from the glory due
the team. In the game with Delaware the
field was covered with slush, and three substitutes were in the Hopkins line. No more
is needed to explain the defeat. In the game
on the following Saturday, with St. John's,
all of the fates—Clotho, Lachesis and Atropos
—were against Hopkins. As a result, no
matter how much ground our fellows gained,
they could not win.
The final game of the season with the
Baltimore Medical College shows well the
For although the
spirit of our eleven.
redoubtable Bridgman was out of the game,
and all the advantage of weight were against
them, the Black and Blue line held tight, and
the Black and Blue backs tore up the line of
the enemy, and the victory was ours.
Let's all give three ringing cheers for the
best team that ever wore the Black and Blue
—the team of 1908.

THE FIFTH REGIMENT MEET.
Although our track men have not started
their regular training, those who were entered
in the meet held at the Fifth Regiment
Armory, on the night after tile St. John's
game did splendid work. Ben. Tappan defeated a good field in the high jump. The
form that he displayed so early in the season.
promises well for his work in future meets.
Keith Martin ran his first race for the
Black and Blue in the 100-yard hurdles. He
won his heat, and in the finals finished a
scant foot behind the winner. Captain Baily
and Leo Gutman ran well in the preliminary
heats of the 100-yard dash, but lack of training prevented them from being placed in the
finals. — Dutch" Breyer started to run the
mile, but he had lost all his wind rooting for
Hopkins against St. John's and dropped out
two laps short of the finish.

ATHLETIC NOTES.
"Billy" Hoffman, '02, captain of the track
team of his year, has been appointed track
coach for the season. The matter of the
coach has been hanging for a long time, and
his final appointment will enable Captain
Baily to get his men down to consistent work.
.Anyone who follows athletics will remember
Mr. Hoffman, who can be depended on to get
out the best team possible.
Mr, Seymour Merrick, '11, has been elected
manager for the football season of 1909. The
good record made by the team this year has
already been the direct cause of the receipt of
many letters from teams of first caliber requesting games, and it looks as if the University would have one of the best schedules in
its history.
The Athletic Board, at a special meeting,
Monday afternoon, awarded the 'Varsity
"H" to the following men: Captain Stockton,
Chauncey Bosley, Eveleth Bridgman, "Dick"
McCabe, "Jack" Fulton, "Babe" Michael,
Harvey Musser, "Ham" Owens, Stoney
Stollenwerck, "Doc" Streett and "Doc"
Bryan. "Bill" Tilghman, Beehler, Frey,
Huck, "Dud" Lawton, "Teedy" Lurman,
"Billy" Martin, Saltzer and Reaney Wolf were
given the "H. A. A." All the awards were
for football, of course.
Another important decision reached by the
board was the determination to drop the Baltimore Medical College and Delaware from
the football schedule. Delaware was dropped
because of the determination of the management that none but teams who are of sufficient
prominence to prove good drawing cards be
played. No one who saw the B. M. C. game
of Thanksgiving day, will need ask why they
were dropped.

THE ALUMNI REUNION. WHAT OF IT?
Well, it's all over. There is one question,
though, which should be, and is, I hope, in
everyone's mind. What has been the result?
What good will the reunion, so much talked
of, bring about? The answers to these, and
similar questions, depend on whether the
former strong college spirit of the old Hopkins men was aroused; it depends on. whether
the present students at Johns Hopkins have
called forth enthusiasm with enthusiasm. You
probably think that it is too late to take up
this last phase of the matter, that we have
shown as much spirit as we could, and that
we can only wait passively for the result. It
is too late to actually catch the attention of
the Alumni, but is that any sort of a reason
why we should remain idle? Do you really
think we have done our best? If not, why
stop? Don't let's have any one ready to 'quit!"
We must all work harder than ever, and
whoop things along, both to keep those of the
Alumni we have, interested, and to fight for
the interest and backing of many more.

REUNION NOTES.
Ninety-two's snappy yell was heard on all
occasions:
Rah, Blue!
Rah, Black!
Johnny Hopkins, Ninety-two!
The cheering and even the songs could be
heard at Roland Park, nearly a mile from
Homewood field, with such distinctness that
hearers could tell the concerted cheers from
the spontaneous yelling.
It would be a great stunt to perpetuate the
war dance" after the game as a sort of
regular custom at the St. John's football game
and at the Swarthmore lacrosse game. The
big crowd that remained to see it this time
proves that outsiders find it interesting.
It was far and away the largest crowd ever
seen at a Hopkins game.
Ever see a Hopkins crowd take a defeat that
way before?

SENIOR CLASS POEM.
The 1909 Hullabaloo Board, in whose hands
the class has placed the selection of the Class
Poem, has decided upon the following conditions:
The competion is open only to members of
the Class of 1909. The poems must be
placed in the hands of the Chief Editor of the
book, before February 1st, 1909. The form
and contents of the poem is left entirely to the
competitors; suggestions may be found in
previous class-books. The author of the best
poem will be appointed Class Poet, and his
composition will be printed in the Hullabaloo,
the board reserving the right to use any of the
unsuccessful poems.
